channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Now Fighting for Ukraine: Volunteers Seeking Revenge Against Russia
item.description: Chechens, Crimean Tatars and people from the former Soviet republics, all with deep historical grievances against Moscow, are eagerly taking up arms for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A volunteer Chechen battalion training last month outside Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: A Vibrant Nightlife Scene Booms in South Africa’s Townships
item.description: Clubs in Khayelitsha, the nation’s second largest township, are attracting Black professionals with entertainment that “we love, we want.”
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The Ocean Canda nightclub on Spine Road in Khayelitsha, a township 20 miles from Cape Town.

item.title: As China Lifts Pandemic Border Controls, Mixed Feelings at Home and Abroad
item.description: Friends and families are planning reunions; tourists are booking flights. But amid the anticipation, there’s a whiff of anxiety.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Tiffany May
item.media:description: People embracing at the international arrivals gate at Beijing International Airport on Sunday, after China opened its borders.

item.title: A Prominent Mexican TV Anchor Departs. Will Dispassionate Coverage Go With Her?
item.description: As a crucial presidential election approaches, a newswoman’s resignation has raised a crucial question: Is her restrained approach also on its way out?
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Denise Maerker in November on the set of “En Punto,” a program on the Televisa network. Ms. Maerker is the most-watched news anchor in Mexico.

item.title: German Police Detain Iranian Citizen on Suspicion of Planning a Chemical Attack
item.description: A 32-year-old Iranian citizen had procured cyanide and ricin in an effort “to commit an Islamist-motivated attack,” the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Christoph Reichwein/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Investigators on Sunday in Castrop-Rauxel, Germany, examining substances that they found during a search of a suspect’s home.

item.title: Iran Executes 2 Men Arrested in Protests
item.description: At least nine other protesters remain on death row, accused of crimes ranging from burning a trash can to killing security forces.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Mohammad Mehdi Karami, center, a national karate champion in Iran, was hanged on Saturday.

item.title: In a Ukraine Workshop, the Quest to Build the Perfect Grenade
item.description: A Ukrainian unit is tinkering with tape, a scale, a 3-D printer and other items to turn a fragmentation grenade into a tank-killer. It’s a steep and risky challenge.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A private in the Ukrainian Army attaching a grenade to a drone in August before using it on a mission over Russian frontline positions near Pokrovske, Ukraine.

item.title: As Asian Societies Age, ‘Retirement’ Just Means More Work
item.description: Across East Asia, populations are graying faster than anywhere else in the world, and while younger generations shrink, older workers are often toiling well into their 70s and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man working in a tea shop in Hong Kong.

item.title: Ukrainians Celebrate Orthodox Christmas at a Holy Site Long Linked to Moscow
item.description: The sermon, a deeply symbolic moment after months of tension with the Moscow-led branch of the church, came as a cease-fire failed to materialize.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Worshipers arriving at Kyiv’s Pechersky Lavra on Saturday for the Orthodox Christmas service, which was held for the first time by the Ukrainian branch of the church, rather than the Russian.

item.title: African Journalists Urge Senegal to Release Pape Alé Niang
item.description: Pape Alé Niang, an investigative reporter, was arrested on charges of disclosing confidential government information. Journalists and rights defenders say he was just doing his job.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Journalists in November in Dakar, Senegal’s capital, protesting the arrest of Pape Alé Niang, an investigative reporter. Many say his case epitomizes the erosion of press freedom in the West African country.

item.title: Prince Harry Claims in Memoir to Have Killed 25 in Afghanistan
item.description: After British news outlets revealed details from his memoir about his military service, Afghan officials and some in the British military expressed criticism.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Anwar Hussein Collection/ROTA/WireImage, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Harry patrolling the town of Garmsir, in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, in 2008.

item.title: Wells Fargo Executive Fired After Air India Urination Allegation
item.description: The executive, for the Indian subsidiary of Wells Fargo, was fired after the investigation became public. Air India faces scrutiny for how it handled the matter.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: An Air India plane at an airport in 2021 in New Delhi.

item.title: Mali Pardons Detained Ivorian Soldiers
item.description: Ivory Coast had said the 49 soldiers were in Mali to provide security for a United Nations peacekeeping mission, but Mali had accused them of being mercenaries.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Ivorian soldiers supporting a United Nations peacekeeping mission in Mali at a parade in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, in 2019.

item.title: New Armored Vehicles Will Help Ukraine Take the Fight to Russia
item.description: The Western allies’ provision of infantry fighting vehicles signals their support for new offensives in coming months, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A German Marder infantry fighting vehicle during a NATO training exercise in Lithuania in October.

item.title: Benedict’s Burial Leaves Francis Alone, and Unbound
item.description: Liberal supporters of Francis, a pope never shy about exercising power, now anticipate a late-breaking season of change.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis on Thursday during the funeral for Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI.

item.title: Broken Promises
item.description: If you’ve already broken your New Year’s resolution, don’t despair. You don’t need a holiday to change your life.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: High Food Prices Rile Up Canadians
item.description: Grocery stores have become a lightning rod for consumer discontent amid inflation and lingering mistrust after a bread price-fixing scandal.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Loblaws, a grocery chain operated by Loblaw Companies, Canada’s largest food retailer.

item.title: Jack Ma, Ant Group Founder, Will Relinquish Control
item.description: Ant Group, the fintech sister company of the e-commerce behemoth Alibaba, is one of China’s most influential companies.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Jack Ma in Mallorca, Spain, in 2021.

item.title: The Toll of Capturing El Chapo’s Son: 10 Soldiers, 19 Cartel Members Dead
item.description: After troops arrested a son of the notorious drug lord known as El Chapo, cartel gunmen tried to free him, resulting in a series of gun battles and thousands of troops called into the fight.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Arturo Hernández/Eyepix Group/Sipa USA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The federal facility where Ovidio Guzmán, the son of the drug lord widely known as El Chapo, was brought in by helicopter on Thursday in Toluca, México.

item.title: Biden Moves to End Doughnut Lures and Other Bear Hunting Tactics in Alaska
item.description: A new rule proposed by the administration would also bar hunters from invading wolf dens to kill pups.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A black bear and her cubs in Kachemak Bay, Alaska.

item.title: Attacks Continue in Ukraine Despite Russia’s Supposed Cease-Fire
item.description: Ukraine never accepted Russia’s unilateral Christmas truce, dismissing it as a hollow ploy, and Russian shelling was as intense as ever in a hotly contested city.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian armored vehicle passing a damaged church in a village in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: Kenyan Gay Rights Activist, Edwin Chiloba, Is Killed
item.description: Edwin Chiloba’s body was dumped on the roadside by a moving vehicle in the country’s west. Police have arrested his friend and are pursuing two others in the case.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: An undated photo of Edwin Chiloba in Eldoret, in western Kenya.

item.title: US to Send $3 Billion in Aid to Ukraine, Including Bradley Fighting Vehicles
item.description: Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, said the administration would also send $682 million to countries on NATO’s eastern flank.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and John Ismay
item.media:description: Bradley Fighting Vehicles waiting to be unloaded in Garkalne, Latvia, in 2017.

item.title: Nate Thayer, Bold Reporter Who Interviewed Pol Pot, Dies at 62
item.description: The “mad genius” journalist scored an exclusive interview with the genocidal Cambodian leader and covered his show trial, another worldwide scoop.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:description: Nate Thayer in 1997, speaking at the Foreign Correspondents’ Club in Bangkok after his interview with Pol Pot.

item.title: Marcio Freire, Renowned Brazilian Surfer, Dies in Portugal
item.description: Mr. Freire began surfing at an early age and starred in a 2016 documentary on the sport. He was 47.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Márcio Freire was featured in “Mad Dogs,” a documentary about his attempt to conquer the giant wave “Jaws” in Hawaii.

item.title: Biden Administration Moves to Tighten Limits on Deadly Air Pollution
item.description: A new rule would, for the first time in a decade, reduce emissions of soot that disproportionately harm communities of color.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:description: The new measure would target fine particulate matter, minuscule pollution that comes from smokestacks, power plants and other industrial activity.

item.title: Belarus Leader Visits a Military Base Where Russian Forces Are Stationed
item.description: Concerns have mounted in recent weeks that Moscow could try to draw Belarus, Ukraine’s northern neighbor, more directly into the war.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighter jets taking part in military exercises between Russia and Belarus near Baranovichi, Belarus, in February of 2022.

item.title: ‘Consciousness’ in Robots Was Once Taboo. Now It’s the Last Word.
item.description: The pursuit of artificial awareness may be humankind’s next moonshot. But it comes with a host of difficult questions.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine Says Allies No Longer View Giving Key Weapons as ‘Taboo’
item.description: The foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, welcomed pledges this week from France, Germany and the United States of military aid that his government had been seeking for months.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparing to fire an American-supplied M777 155-millimeter howitzer at Russian positions in the Donetsk region, in eastern Ukraine, in May.

item.title: Military Investigation Reveals How the U.S. Botched a Drone Strike in Kabul
item.description: Documents obtained through a lawsuit reveal how biases led to the deadly August 2021 blunder, and that officials made misleading statements concealing their assessment of civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: Azmat Khan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and neighbors at the site of a U.S. drone strike that killed 10 civilians in August 2021.

item.title: The Lying Congressman
item.description: George Santos is stretching the tolerance for lies in U.S. politics.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Alejandra Villa Loarca/Newsday, via Getty Images
item.media:description: George Santos with other Republican officials after Election Day in November.

item.title: Here Are the People Iran Sentenced to Death in Its Protest Crackdown
item.description: An updated look at the Iranians marked for execution in the government’s attempt to curb a monthslong uprising.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An image from social media of Iranians who in October were marking 40 days since the death of Mahsa Amini in the custody of Iran’s morality police.

item.title: She Is Africa’s First Heat Officer. Can She Make Her City Livable?
item.description: Eugenia Kargbo remembers when Sierra Leone’s capital was greener and cooler, and is now trying to help the city combat rising temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Yagazie Emezi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eugenia Kargbo in Freetown’s Congo Market, by the newly installed market canopies.

item.title: China’s Covid Surge Threatens Villages as Lunar New Year Approaches
item.description: Millions are expected to travel home this month, spreading Covid to rural communities where health care services are woefully underdeveloped.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Joy Dong, Claire Fu and Olivia Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The emergency unit of the main hospital in Hua County, which encompasses Maxiaoji Village, on Wednesday.

item.title: Can Australia Escape a Recession?
item.description: “Whether it’s a technical recession or not, we certainly are going to be in for difficult times,” one economist said.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: New Year’s Eve celebrations in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: Battered and Strained by War, Ukraine’s Economy Adapts to Survive
item.description: After 10 months of Russian destruction, Ukraine’s economy shrank by 30 percent. But companies have packed up and moved, switched products and found support abroad.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: An idle factory near the front lines in Soledar, in Ukraine’s Donetsk region, in August.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Responses to Russia’s ordering of a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near the front lines in Kreminna, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, on Thursday

item.title: Putin Calls a 36-Hour Cease-Fire, but Ukraine and U.S. Are Skeptical
item.description: The cease-fire would coincide with the Eastern Orthodox Christmas on Saturday, but Kremlin adversaries and some analysts call it a ploy for military and political advantage.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Fighters from Ukraine’s Karpatska Sich Battalion in a church on Dec. 25 that was destroyed by shelling and reportedly looted by Russian forces during their occupation, in the Lyman district in the Donetsk region.

item.title: What Is the Bradley Fighting Vehicle?
item.description: Often mistaken for a tank, the decades-old Bradley offers a compromise between traditional tank firepower and an armored personnel carrier.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American soldiers driving a Bradley Fighting Vehicle in northeastern Syria in 2021.

item.title: Kenneth Rowe, Who Defected From North Korea With His Jet, Dies at 90
item.description: Two months after the Korean War armistice, he handed America an intelligence bonanza with his headline-making flight in a Soviet-made MIG.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Lt. No Kum-Sok of the North Korean Air Force in 1953, the year he defected. He changed his name to Kenneth Rowe and became an American citizen.

item.title: U.S. Officials Repatriate a Looted Relic to the Palestinian Authority
item.description: As the object, a carved spoon, was handed back at a ceremony in Bethlehem, officials said it was the first time the United States had repatriated an antiquity to the Palestinian government.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg
item.media:credit: via the Manhattan District Attorney's Office
item.media:description: A cosmetic spoon carved from ivory, which officials said had been looted, was returned to the Palestinian Authority.

item.title: For the State Department, Now It’s Türkiye, Not Turkey
item.description: The department will use the Turkish-language spelling in “most formal, diplomatic, and bilateral contexts” after a request from the country’s embassy, a spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Murat Kula/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has publicly opposed the use of the Anglicized spelling for his country and has pushed for the rest of the world to use its Turkish-language name.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Proposes a Short Cease-Fire
item.description: Also, Kevin McCarthy loses yet another bid to become House speaker, and the week in culture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A damaged church in a village in the Donetsk region on Thursday.

item.title: Twin Car Explosions Kill More than 20 in Somalia
item.description: A terrorist group, Al Shabab, claimed responsibility for the attacks, which came as the militants lose control of towns and villages to a government offensive.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Security forces in Somalia’s capital, Mogadishu, ahead of a presidential election last year.

item.title: Church Lays Benedict to Rest, if Not Its Divisions
item.description: An extraordinary period for the modern church ended with Francis presiding over the funeral of his retired predecessor. Some conservatives found the ceremony too modest for their standard-bearer.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis presiding over the funeral for Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI in St. Peter’s Square on Thursday.

item.title: El Chapo’s Son Is Captured by Mexican Authorities for 2nd Time
item.description: The arrest of Ovidio Guzmán López was a victory for the Mexican government. He had been briefly detained in 2019, but was released after cartel gunmen overpowered law enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Steve Fisher
item.media:description: A vehicle burns following clashes between federal forces and armed groups in Culiacan, Mexico, on Thursday.

item.title: Some Find Fault With Francis’ Homily for Benedict
item.description: The former pope’s supporters, who include conservatives, said Francis’ approach seemed paltry in comparison to Benedict’s homily at the funeral of Pope John Paul II.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis’ homily for his predecessor, Benedict XVI, has drawn some criticism from the church’s conservative wing.

item.title: How a Nuclear Dump in Taiwan Created a Generation of Activists
item.description: For members of a Taiwanese tribe, a waste site on their island serves as a painful reminder of the government’s broken promises, and a symbol of their long struggle for greater autonomy.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:description: The nuclear waste dump site on the Taiwanese island of Lanyu. The government in the 1970s built the site to store thousands of barrels of low-level radioactive waste produced by nuclear power plants on the main island.

item.title: Biden Announces Major Crackdown on Illegal Border Crossings
item.description: President Biden, who is under pressure to confront a surge in migration at the border, said he would visit El Paso on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Eileen Sullivan and Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: Mr. Biden described the new approach as one intended to expand opportunities for migrants.

item.title: In a phone call with Putin, Turkey’s president calls for a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neighbors helping to clear belongings on Sunday from a house in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was damaged by a Russian strike.

item.title: Russia Pardons Some Prisoners Who Fought in Ukraine, Reports Say
item.description: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the Wagner paramilitary group, is seen in a video congratulating men for completing their military contracts.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Alina Lobzina
item.media:description: A pro-military poster near the Wagner Group’s headquarters in St. Petersburg, Russia, in November.

item.title: Prince Harry’s Memoir Alleges Physical Attack by William, According to Report
item.description: “He knocked me to the floor,” Harry recounts of the alleged assault by Prince William, according to The Guardian, which said it had obtained a copy of Harry’s coming book.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The princes and their wives in Windsor, England, in September. Prince Harry, second from left, said that he had been attacked by his brother, William, right, during a furious argument over Harry’s marriage to Meghan Markle, left.

item.title: Most of Bakhmut Has Been Destroyed in Ukraine War, Official Says
item.description: Russia has continued to press an offensive aimed at capturing the eastern city, after suffering a string of setbacks elsewhere in Ukraine in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Walking past a destroyed building in Bakhmut last month.

item.title: Violence in the N.F.L.
item.description: In professional football, danger is at the root of any given play.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:description: Buffalo Bills fans at a vigil for Damar Hamlin at Highmark Stadium in Orchard Park, New York.

item.title: Pope Francis’ Homily for Benedict Calls Him a ‘Faithful Friend’ of Jesus
item.description: Pope Francis’ short speech honored the former pontiff, whose life’s work was meditating on the life of Jesus, and who faced many challenges before retiring in 2013.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis delivering the homily at the funeral on Thursday.

item.title: The Funeral for Pope Benedict XVI, in Photos
item.description: Benedict XVI was laid to rest in a ceremony that marked the end of an unusual arrangement during which he lived on the Vatican grounds after having resigned in 2013.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The coffin of Pope Benedict XVI was carried out of St Peter’s Basilica on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The Russian authorities have laid the blame for a deadly Ukrainian strike on their soldiers themselves.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Russian soldier taking a photo on his mobile phone at the Mariupol theater in April.

item.title: Ukraine Finds Sexual Crimes in Regions Russia Occupied
item.description: Investigators have uncovered widespread evidence of abuse by Moscow’s forces, including rape and forced nudity. Kremlin officials have repeatedly denied accusations of rights violations.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Laura Boushnak
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha, a 26-year-old Ukrainian, has faced sexual violence by Russian soldiers when she was detained in Kherson.

item.title: Ukraine Claims Heavy Russian Losses in Waves of Missile Strikes
item.description: Kyiv says its forces have killed or wounded hundreds of Russian soldiers in a series of pinpoint attacks. Russia has confirmed only one of three waves of strikes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:description: A Ukrainian High Mobility Artillery Rocket System, or HIMARS, firing on Russian positions in the Kherson region in November.

item.title: E.U. Urges Nations to Require Negative Covid Tests for Travelers From China
item.description: In a diplomatically fraught move, the bloc advised its 27 members to put restrictions in place as Chinese tourists prepare to return to global destinations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: A Covid screening site for passengers from China at Leonardo da Vinci international airport in Rome on Dec. 29.

item.title: Russian Troops’ Use of Cellphones Is a Persistent, Lethal Danger
item.description: Ukrainian artillery targets Russian soldiers by pinpointing their phone signals. Despite the deadly results, Russian troops keep defying a ban on cellphone use near the front.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Yousur Al-Hlou
item.media:description: A Russian soldier taking a photo on his mobile phone at the Mariupol theater in April.
